image.altText: Emergency teams on a foggy road

items.synopsis: Ten people have died and multiple others have been injured in a bus crash in the NSW Hunter Valley, with emergency services called to Wine Country Drive at Greta just after 11.30pm on Sunday.

title.children: 10 people die in Hunter Valley crash after wedding bus rolls off roundabout

image.altText: Ambulances attend a scene by the road in the dark.

items.synopsis: At least 10 people have died and multiple others have been injured in a bus crash in the NSW Hunter Valley last night. Follow live.

title.children: Bus 'appeared to be coming from a wedding', Cessnock mayor says

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has sent his condolences to those involved in the fatal bus crash where 10 people died and 11 remained injured. "All Australians waking up to tragic news from the Hunter send our deepest sympathies to the loved ones of those killed in this horrific bus tragedy," Albanese wrote on Twitter. While the cause of the crash is not yet know, Cessnock's mayor said the bus appeared to be returning from a wedding. "For a day of joy to end in such devastating loss is cruel indeed," Albanese added. The prime minister also thanked first responders.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Prime minister sends 'deepest sympathies'

children.content: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has sent his condolences to those involved in the fatal bus crash where 10 people died and 11 remained injured.
"All Australians waking up to tragic news from the Hunter send our deepest sympathies to the loved ones of those killed in this horrific bus tragedy," Albanese wrote on Twitter.
While the cause of the crash is not yet know, Cessnock's mayor said the bus appeared to be returning from a wedding.
"For a day of joy to end in such devastating loss is cruel indeed," Albanese added.
The prime minister also thanked first responders.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Peta Hughes is a local business owner in Branxton in New South Wales, a town just slightly north of Greta where the fatal bus crash happened. She spoke to News Breakfast earlier and says the roundabout where the bus crashed had been reduced to one lane due to being under construction for "the last couple of months". "The roundabout is under construction at the moment," she said. "So it was a one lane roundabout and they're currently extending and doing road works on it. "They've got barriers and the safety bollards and things up around there. It's a 40km/h zone."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Roundabout reduced to one lane due to construction, local business owner says

children.content: is a local business owner in Branxton in New South Wales, a town just slightly north of Greta where the fatal bus crash happened.
She spoke to News Breakfast earlier and says the roundabout where the bus crashed had been reduced to one lane due to being under construction for "the last couple of months".
"The roundabout is under construction at the moment," she said.
"So it was a one lane roundabout and they're currently extending and doing road works on it.
"They've got barriers and the safety bollards and things up around there. It's a 40km/h zone."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Cessnock Mayor Jay Suvaal is currently speaking to News Breakfast and says the bus appears to have been returning from a wedding when the crash happened. "We're still waiting for further details to come to light as the investigations continue," he said. "We don't know the circumstances around the crash at the moment. But it does appear that it was a wedding chartered bus that had been coming from a wedding earlier that day."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bus 'appeared to be coming from a wedding', Cessnock mayor says

children.content: is currently speaking to News Breakfast and says the bus appears to have been returning from a wedding when the crash happened.
"We're still waiting for further details to come to light as the investigations continue," he said.
"We don't know the circumstances around the crash at the moment. But it does appear that
it was a wedding chartered bus that had been coming from a wedding earlier that day."

image.altText: Daniel Lees wears a grey t-shirt in front of a home's front door.

items.synopsis: Daniel Lees's home ownership dreams were shattered after a Gold Coast developer ripped up his vacant land contract without his consent and then offered to sell it back to him for $200,000 more. In Queensland, this is legal.

title.children: Daniel had a contract with a developer. One decision left him priced out of the housing market

image.altText: A tropical island from above

items.synopsis: Emergency services were called to the area near Double Island late last night.

title.children: A man has died and two have been rescued after boat overturns near Port Douglas

image.altText: smiling woman with two smiling young  boys

items.synopsis: Jacqueline Morton has four sustainable tiny homes on her 32-acre property, but the local council is kicking out the vulnerable residents living on her land.

title.children: Behind the smile lies a fear of homelessness as tiny home residents told to move on

image.altText: Large crowd, generic image, good for population stories.

items.synopsis: A lack of data on how consumers are responding to monetary policy could lead the Reserve Bank to raise rates into a recession. And what if that's difficult to escape? It's a critical economic question right now, writes David Taylor.

title.children: The economy is in a race to the bottom and nobody wants to win

image.altText: A man sits on a folding chair on the sideline of a soccer game. In the foreground players chasing the ball stream past.

items.synopsis: Australian soccer's governing body is taking a cut from every local bet placed on games at all levels, including amateur suburban competitions.

title.children: The man on the sidelines helping punters around the world bet on this suburban soccer game

image.altText: Tennis star Novak Djokovic smiles as he holds the French Open trophy while wearing a jacket with "23" on it.

items.synopsis: Novak Djokovic breaks more tennis records with a defeat of Casper Ruud to win his 23rd grand slam title at the French Open.

title.children: Novak Djokovic makes history at French Open, wins record 23rd men's grand slam title

image.altText: The Australian team gather around Pat Cummins, who holds the mace trophy awarded to the World Test Championship winners

items.synopsis: Australia has won the World Test Championship Final for the first time, defeating India by 209 runs at The Oval thanks to a commanding fifth-day bowling performance.

title.children: Australia's bowlers rip through India to secure World Test Championship victory

image.altText: Man in blue shirt and straw hat looking at camera

items.synopsis: Greenvale Energy hopes a geothermal plant, using hot rocks technology, could be up and running by 2026, with others to follow suit.

title.children: John's town was a geothermal hub until it failed, but one company thinks it will be different

image.altText: A sign outside Banksia Hill Detention Centre with a police officer nearby.

items.synopsis: The WA Department of Justice is accused of intimidating and bullying staff who speak about Western Australia's juvenile detention facilities.

title.children: Leaked Department of Justice email shows warning of jail time for guards at Banksia Hill over workplace conversations

image.altText: A man stands between two women. He's smiling. The women are pixelated.

items.synopsis: Concerned Catholics of Tasmania wants an independent investigation into Catholic Education Tasmania after its executive director apologised for inappropriate behaviour towards to staff members.

title.children: Concerned Catholics want investigation into allegations of inappropriate behaviour by head of catholic schools in Tasmania

image.altText: A marijuna plant.

items.synopsis: Bureau of Crime Statistics and Research findings suggest the NSW Cannabis Caution Scheme has "indirect bias" built into its eligibility criteria.

title.children: Claims of police bias as study finds Aboriginal adults caught with cannabis more likely to be charged

image.altText: Composite image of Shellie Morris, Astrid Jorgenson, Tim Winton and Barry Humphries.

items.synopsis: Prominent Australians including author Tim Winton and late comedian Barry Humphries are appointed to the Order of Australia, in the first year women outnumber men on the honours list.

title.children: More women than men appointed to Order of Australia for first time

image.altText: A woman stands thoughtfully in front of colourful artwork

items.synopsis: A life dedicated to service and paving the way for Aboriginal leaders comes full circle today as Carol Martin is recognised as part of the King's Birthday Honours list.

title.children: First Aboriginal woman elected to any Australian parliament honoured with Order of Australia Medal

image.altText: US highway collapse

items.synopsis: A portion of a major US highway collapsed in Philadelphia after a vehicle caught fire underneath it, city officials say.

title.children: US highway collapses in Philadelphia after vehicle engulfed by fire

image.altText: A police officer stands in front of two Australian flags.

items.synopsis: WA Police say they are mourning the death of 28-year-old Constable Anthony Woods, who has died after being run over while trying to make an arrest following a police pursuit.

title.children: WA Police officer dies after being run over in line of duty

image.altText: Algae in a jar

items.synopsis: As regional communities continue to grow, the need to safely treat wastewater increases. One trial in Queensland has reduced the treatment time from 60 days to two weeks.

title.children: Supercharged poo-eating algae speeds up waste treatment

items.synopsis: Michael Travis Leake, a US musician and former paratrooper, is arrested in Moscow on drug dealing charges.

title.children: Russia arrests US musician on drug dealing charges

image.altText: A Pacific worker throws a pumpkin onto a sorting line.

items.synopsis: Fruit and vegetable growers say they'll be forced to employ fewer workers from the Pacific when the Australian government introduces changes to its foreign labour scheme.

title.children: Farmers call for rethink on Pacific worker scheme as union warns against 'hysteria'

image.altText: Woman with dark hair and dark glasses in a red jumper. There is a lamp behind her. She is facing us but looking to the right.

items.synopsis: Kerry has seen three family members battle motor neurone disease. But she’s hopeful for a cure  and experts are on her side.

title.children: Kerry lost her daughter and ex-husband to MND. Now, her son is living with the condition

image.altText: A woman holds a open palmed hand partially in front of her face.

items.synopsis: Former Scottish first minister Nicola Sturgeon has been arrested and held for more than seven hours on Sunday after voluntarily attending an interview over a police probe into the fate of funds for her pro-independence Scottish National Party.

title.children: Scottish ex-leader Nicola Sturgeon released after arrest by police in party finance probe

image.altText: a young man sits in a stairwell giving the camera a thumbs-up

items.synopsis: The Noosa man, who was arrested in Aceh province after injuring an Indonesian fisherman, has arrived home.

title.children: Bodhi Risby-Jones arrives back in Queensland after alleged drunken rampage in Indonesia

image.altText: Dalai Lama

items.synopsis: Tibetan Buddhists may face a future of duelling Dalai Lamas: one born in exile who will receive traditional religious training, the other a mouthpiece of the Communist Party, writes John Powers.

title.children: China's prepared for battle over the Dalai Lama's reincarnation — and survival is at stake

image.altText: Spain clams

items.synopsis: Clam collecting in the expansive inlets of Spain's north-western region of Galicia is a deep-rooted tradition handed down from generation to generation, with the workers predominantly women.

title.children: Meet Spain's 'peasant farmers of the sea', the women who spend their days digging for clams

image.altText: Ukrainian soldiers stand in front of a building with a Ukrainian flag on it

items.synopsis: Kyiv says the Ukrainian troops captured a village from Russian forces in the south-east, as Wagner boss Yevgeny Prigozhin defies Russia's defence minister's order that all "volunteer detachments" are to sign contracts with his ministry.

title.children: Ukraine reports 'first results' of counterattack, as Wagner boss rejects signing contract with Russia's Defence Ministry

image.altText: Two you women stand in an alley holding vegetables

items.synopsis: Food waste is a big issue, especially when there is a cost-of-living crisis. And while "dumpster diving" is not encouraged, with strict guidelines, it is one of the ways Tasmanian volunteers are helping to keep people fed.

title.children: These women don't want good food wasted so even 'dumpster diving' is on the menu — to a point

image.altText: A par of legs dressed in thermal leggings on a chequered blanket with a laptop.

items.synopsis: Almost 5 million Australians claimed work from home expenses last financial year, but the ATO has changed the methods you can use to claim tax deductions this tax time. Landlords renting out property and crypto investors are also under focus.

title.children: New methods to claim tax deductions for working from home and one might leave you with a lower return

image.altText: A young woman with brown hair stands on a dock

items.synopsis: Would you want to share a room in a share house with another person? It's one option that's popped up on the market, and Australia's reserve bank governor wants you to consider it. We asked young people how they are coping with the ongoing rental crisis.

title.children: Alivia doesn't want 'to live with randoms' just to get a roof over her head

image.altText: A dingo standing on a rocky ledge looking out into the distance.

items.synopsis: Dingo or wild dog? The question has divided farmers and conservationists for years, but new research suggests the animals were dingoes all along.

title.children: DNA tests find most wild dogs are pure dingoes, as farmers fight to protect livestock

image.altText: A big field of large bright sunflowers are open and pointing in different directions as the sun set on a house on the horizon

items.synopsis: A plan to produce vegetable oil for biofuel could see a Queensland town recrowned the sunflower capital, after disease and market pressures wiped them from the landscape.

title.children: Disease decimated Australia's sunflower capital, but could biofuel bring it back?
